title: Customers may bear cost of extending pay powers
text:
Dr David said if the BEAR was extended in its current form it would require smaller health insurers to make new appointments at significant expense.

“For some organisations that are the same size or smaller than a community bank, the appointment of a chief risk officer for instance is a huge undertaking. The question is, are there cost benefits for consumers? It may be a case of diminishing returns.”

Among the other requirements of the framework are the need to register accountable persons, submit accountability maps, defer bonuses for up to seven years and introduce clawback provisions of up to four years after they are paid out.

FSC boss Sally Loane said it was important there was no impact on consumers. Lucas Jarvis, Eventive Photography

The Financial Services Council, which represents more than 100 companies, said it wanted to better understand how it would be rolled out before giving its unconditional support.

Council CEO Sally Loane said she supported the extension of the BEAR in principle, but the FSC wanted to be sure there was not an impact on the consumers of its products.

“The FSC will continue to work constructively with Treasury and relevant agencies as the royal commission recommendations are implemented, so that any unintended consequences that may impact consumers, such as unwarranted regulatory burden, are avoided,” Ms Loane said.

A spokesman for the ASX said it was aware of the plan to extend the BEAR. He said the securities exchange had already performed significant work on its risk management, governance and accountability processes as part of a broad review following the equity market outage of 2016.

Advertisement

“It’s clearly a matter of interest to us, and we look forward to seeing the detail,” the spokesman said.

“We are preparing ourselves for this likelihood and believe we’re well placed to implement.”

Extending the BEAR to cover all prudentially regulated institutions was recommendation 6.8 in the Hayne royal commission’s final report. Commissioner Hayne, however, did not mention private health insurers specifically.

Modelled on the BEAR framework that covers the banks and is overseen by APRA, the financial services executive and accountability regime – or FEAR – will be operated by ASIC, which is understood to be pushing for a wider application of the net to capture more companies.

During the initial phases of the rollout of the BEAR regime, APRA said the first attempts from the banks were clumsy and advised the smaller banks that followed to avoid “vague or non-specific descriptions” and to focus on “clarity of wording”.

“The early ones were good first attempts but needed work ... it's legislation, so you want to pass and you want to pass clearly," APRA’s former heard of policy Pat Brennan said last year.
description: Representatives for the financial services sector and private health insurers say consumers may pay the price of extending the BEAR regime more broadly.
